campaign.story:
From the most famous city in the history of fantasy comes a sword-and-sorcery adventure to test the finest gamers! The Greatest Thieves in Lankhmar is a level 3 Dungeon Crawl Classics boxed set that sends characters into the hot cellars beneath Thieves’ House, across the sooty rooftops of the City of Sevenscore Thousand Smokes, and on to a mad dash through the palace of the Overlord. Featuring design leads Harley Stroh and Marc Bruner with cover art by Doug Kovacs, this boxed set comes with everything you need to run an epic adventure over several sessions, whether you run it as a tournament or as part of an ongoing campaign.
When you open the box, you’ll be in the company of legends. The Greatest Thieves in Lankhmar was first run as a tournament at Gen Con 2019, where 20 nationally competitive teams competed over four fantastic days and three hard-fought rounds. Characters died alone, as they were lost beneath Thieves’ House, flung from rooftops to die upon the hard cobbles, or felled by mind-bending puzzles deep within the Rainbow Palace.
No character has ever survived to the end of this adventure in tournament play. Could yours be the first? After 44% of tables experienced TPKs, and nearly 6 in 10 PCs were killed, one team triumphed to win the tournament. They had the high score under the tournament rules, but were still TPK'd in the end. Every player character to advance to round three has died on that level! 
This Kickstarter brings a tournament adventure to players worldwide. One of the stretch goals is a global organized play of the tournament module. The International Tournament of Thieves could be your home group’s chance to see their photograph and scores in print!
Lankhmar: The City of Seven-Thousand Score Smokes and twice as many thieves. But after tonight, one band will rule over all the others.
Is your canting crew daring, cunning, and lucky enough to be crowned the Greatest Thieves in Lankhmar? Grab your dirk, a drink, and your tools. Lankhmar awaits.
The Greatest Thieves in Lankhmar will be published in a boxed format, with all the materials necessary to run it as it was first seen at Gen Con 2019. The box will include all three rounds of the original adventure, plus player handouts, maps, scoring sheets, a judge’s pack, a player’s pack, and more. You can also run the adventure as part of an ongoing campaign. Regardless of how your players experience it, you’ll be able to score them using the adventure’s scoring system, and compare their scores to the Gen Con contenders.
Mockup of what the boxed set will look like (image not final)
Is this adventure only for thieves? The Greatest Thieves in Lankhmar uses the term “thieves” in a broad sense. Anyone who steals is a thief, regardless of character class! The tournament pregenerated characters include warriors and wizards, as well as thieves. You can play this adventure with any set of characters.
Do I need to own the DCC Lankhmar boxed set? The adventure includes a primer on DCC Lankhmar rules, so you can play it with simply the DCC RPG core rulebook. Of course, if you have the DCC Lankhmar boxed set, that will make the experience even more rich.
What is DCC RPG? The Dungeon Crawl Classics Role Playing Game is a modern RPG that reflects D&D’s origin-point concepts with decades-later rules editions. From the company that was publishing old-school modules before the OSR ever existed, DCC RPG is not an old-school clone, but a re-imagining of what D&D could have been, utilizing the game’s primary sources of inspiration. To quote from the back cover:
You’re no hero.
You're an adventurer: a reaver, a cutpurse, a heathen-slayer, a tight-lipped warlock guarding long-dead secrets. You seek gold and glory, winning it with sword and spell, caked in the blood and filth of the weak, the dark, the demons, and the vanquished. There are treasures to be won deep underneath, and you shall have them.
Return to the glory days of fantasy with the Dungeon Crawl Classics Role Playing Game. Adventure as 1974 intended you to, with modern rules grounded in the origins of sword & sorcery. Fast play, cryptic secrets, and a mysterious past await you: turn the page… 
You can learn more from this prior Kickstarter for the game's 4th printing. You can buy the 7th printing here. 
Does your home group think they’re great dungeon crawlers? This adventure will make them think again.
Because our tournament modules are played at Gen Con over a large sample of tables and judges, we are able to quantify their danger level. Based on this quantification we have a rating system to assess each tournament adventure’s lethality. At Goodman Games, we call this the Count Dante rating.
The Greatest Thieves in Lankhmar receives a Count Dante rating of III (on a scale of I to VI). In tournament play, the adventure killed 74 of the 129 PCs who participated, or an average of 0.57 fatalities for every PC in the game. Over the course of three rounds, 44% of the tables to run this adventure suffered TPKs. (TPK stands for Total Party Kill.)
The published adventure module will include complete statistics from the Gen Con tournament, including judge and team stats, most popular pre-gens, and even deadliest rooms. For example: 70% of PCs to reach area 2-5 died in that room.
In other words, if your players think they’re hot stuff, this adventure will put that to the test. Competitive dungeon crawlers at America’s largest tabletop gaming convention suffered 57% fatality rates and a 44% TPK rate. But one team did triumph, and they were crowned The Greatest Thieves in Lankhmar. How will your home group fare?
Lankhmar is the most famous fantasy city of all time. It was created in 1937 by Fritz Leiber, who went on to coin the phrase “sword-and-sorcery” to describe the genre of which it is part. Lankhmar’s most famous residents are Fafhrd and the Gray Mouser. If you have not read the many wonderful stories of their adventures, you should start immediately! They are among the greatest fantasy stories ever written.
Lankhmar has a special place in tabletop role playing history. Its mythology appears in the original AD&D Deities & Demigods supplement, and TSR published a licensed Lankhmar setting many years ago. Goodman Games continued that heritage by publishing our own DCC Lankhmar setting in 2019. The Greatest Thieves in Lankhmar is part of the DCC Lankhmar line of products, officially licensed by the estate of Fritz Leiber.
The Greatest Thieves in Lankhmar was first run as our Gen Con 2019 tournament adventure. Goodman Games has been running RPG tournaments at Gen Con for more than a decade, and this year we are expanding even further to accommodate more than 500 players at Gen Con 2020. We are proud to continue a Gen Con tournament tradition that traces its heritage to the earliest days of TSR D&D tournaments.
The tournament is a true test of skill, for both judges and players alike. Under Gen Con conditions, each round is timed. At home you can play without a time limit, should you choose. But even without a time limit, the puzzles are challenging and the encounters are deadly!
The DCC RPG horde gathers for the tournament awards ceremony at last year's Gen Con!
At Gen Con, the Gong of Doom is used to sound the start of each tournament round. As PCs die, their players must make the Walk of Shame to sound the gong. This symbolizes the crack of thunder as their gods call home the souls of the fallen. The Gong of Doom is adorned with plaques to commemorate the winners of each annual tournament. When it is unveiled at Gen Con 2020, it will feature a new plaque with the names of the 2019 winners: Team Oh, God! with players Jim Batka, Mathew Batka, Joe Batke and Jason Cefaratti. If you’ll be at Gen Con, make sure to visit our game area to see the Gong of Doom! And if you play at home, you may even want to get a gong of your own.
The Gong of Doom!
One of the most exciting parts of this publication is that everyone in the world can play the same adventure at the same time, and then compare their scores! At a certain stretch goal level (see below), we will add the International Tournament of Thieves.
What is the International Tournament of Thieves? It is your chance to immortalize your home group!
At this stretch goal, we will work overtime to distribute a beta PDF of The Greatest Thieves in Lankhmar to backers. Once you have the beta, you will have several weeks to review it and schedule your home game. We will then set up a format where you can report your scores and submit a photo of your home group. The finished print product will then be updated to include your home group’s names, score, and possibly their photograph (space permitting). This is your chance to be part of an international tournament, and see your home group in print!
The Gen Con 2019 Tournament Champions and the greatest thieves in all Lankhmar. When you play the adventure at home, can you out-score them?
The Greatest Thieves in Lankhmar is available in print and PDF formats. There is a consolidated pledge level containing the Lankhmar printed items and Lankhmar-specific add-ons. This is available for $250, a $20 savings on the individual purchase price. 
A similar PDF edition, featuring all the electronic Lankhmar items, is available for $130, a $12 savings. The PDF edition has the same content as the print edition, but of course no physical box. 
Shipping costs are not included in the initial pledge levels. These will be assessed after the Kickstarter. Please note that this will be a weighty boxed set. USA shipments can go via affordable media mail, but international shipments may be expensive. If you'd like an estimated shipping cost, please message us. 
These add-on items are included in several of the pledge levels, at a discount when purchased as a bundle. Check the pledge levels first!
DCC RPG Core Rulebook ($40). Don’t own DCC RPG yet? You can add on your own copy here!
Luck Tokens ($40). Since first launching DCC Lankhmar, we have had constant requests for Luck tokens. These are used for the Fleeting Luck mechanic in DCC Lankhmar, which allows luck to be given – and taken away – live at the tabletop. For the first time outside of a convention, we will be offering Luck tokens for sale! There are a number of new designs, which you can see in this update. As an add-on to this Kickstarter, you can add a tube of 40 Luck tokens for $40.
Tournament Supplies ($20). At Gen Con, all judges receive a printed scoring sheet for each round, and each player receives a printed player pack. The boxed set includes a player pack and judge’s scoring sheets, designed to be photocopied for home use. If you would like to run a larger tournament (or just have fancier materials for your home group), you can add on a set of tournament supplies. This includes five printed player packs and three extra sets of printed scoring sheets. (You can add on multiple sets if you'd like to run a lot of tournaments.)
DCC Lankhmar Boxed Set ($60). You can add on the DCC Lankhmar boxed set for $60.
DCC Lankhmar adventure modules ($10 each). There are 11 DCC Lankhmar adventures. You can add them on at $10 each. These are:
DCCL#1: Gang Lords of Lankhmar
DCCL#2: The Fence’s Fortuitous Folly
DCCL#3: Acting Up in Lankhmar
DCCL#4: Violence for Votishal
DCCL#5: Blasphemy and Larceny in Lankhmar
DCCL#6: Cheating Death
DCCL#7: A Dozen Lankhmar Locations
DCCL#8: The Land of Eight Cities
DCCL#9: Grave Matters
DCCL#10: Unholy Nights
DCCL#11: Rats of Ilthmar
Other tournament modules. You can add on our previous Gen Con tournament modules. Riders on the Phlogiston ($30) was our 2018 Gen Con tournament, and The Black Heart of Thakulon The Undying ($20) was our 2017 Gen Con tournament.
The great thing about a boxed set is you can fill it with lots of stuff! We have big plans to expand this project if the fates and our fans support it. These include a bonus adventure Dicing With Death (which lets PCs keep playing as shades after their death in the tournament), upgrades to handouts and the poster maps, more encounters, and the International Tournament of Thieves! Join us on our flight through Thieves' House and let's make it happen! 
Our Gen Con tournament would not be possible without a dedicated team of incredible judges. Here is our shout-out and thanks. These judges will make your game a blast. They will also probably kill you. If you get the chance to game with them at Gen Con, do so!
Mike Bolam
Marc Bruner

Tim Deschene 
Jeff Goad
Aaron Koelman
Terry Olson
Haley Skach
Jim Skach
Harley Stroh
James Walls
The Greatest Thieves in Lankhmar adventure was originally conceived by Harley Stroh. Harley and Marc Bruner were lead designers on the project. 
Our design process for tournament adventures is centered around an overarching plot design, supported by a hyper-focus on making each encounter unique and special. Each person in the dungeon design team focuses their energies on just a few encounters, which gives each and every encounter in the adventure its own extraordinary feel. 
The final dungeon design included contributions from writers Julian Bernick, Michael Bolam, Bob Brinkman, Alasdair Cunningham, Eric Daum, Tim Deschene, Marzio Muscedere, Terry Olson, and Thorin Thompson.
Harley Stroh first ran Keep on the Borderlands for his brother and their parents at the age of eight. Since then he has published nearly 50 adventure modules, short stories, campaign settings, and gaming supplements, and has written for Goodman Games, Wizards of the Coast, Dave Arneson’s Blackmoor, and the Hobonomicon. He eagerly awaits the release of Dungeon Crawl Classics #100: The Music of Spheres (is Chaos) and is hard at work writing adventures for Goodman Games’ Dying Earth and Empire of the East lines, as well as contributing to David Baity’s Dark Trails RPG. But, in his heart of hearts, he really just wants to write an adventure worthy of a Doug Kovacs cover. When not missing deadlines for Goodman Games, Harley is falling down on concrete at the nearest skatepark, or is broken down in the desert in a VW bus, with his family and their dog.
Marc Bruner first contributed to Goodman Games as author of the 2016 Holiday DCC module Twilight of the Winter Solstice, and since then has gone on to pen adventures for DCC RPG, MCC RPG, and Dinosaur Crawl Classics along with the occasional web site article. He has also served as the co-designer for the DCC Open tournament held at Gen Con since 2017, helping to guide hundreds of players to their doom within the dark tombs of the multi-verse. He is currently lead designer on DCC Dying Earth, a setting for DCC RPG based on the works of Jack Vance and licensed from the estate of the author. When Marc isn’t gaming or writing, he runs amok with his four kids and paramour in lovely Austin, TX.
Julian Bernick cut his teeth on AD&D at the tender age of 13 and spent the next ten years balancing obsessions with D&D and comic books.  He lives in South Minneapolis, where he co-founded the Minneapolis DCC RPG Society with Judge Gary Fortuin. In addition to freelance writing for DCC, MCC and Umerican Survival Guide, he is the annoying voice on the Spellburn podcast, dedicated to DCC and old-school gaming. He’s also a poetry editor for Whistling Shade magazine and has published poems in journals and anthologies, with his first book-length publication, Castle Bash, scheduled for 2020.
Mike Bolam first discovered D&D by playing a neighbor's copy of the Dungeon! board game in the early 80s. After playing RPGs occasionally through high school, Mike really jumped back into gaming in the mid-2000s, just in time for the resurgence of old school style play. He has been regularly running DCC RPG games since the Road Crew kicked off in 2013, and has been a DCC RPG Open Tournament Judge at Gen Con from the start. When he isn’t gaming, Mike can usually be found watching pro-wrestling or playing with his death metal band, Abysme.
Bob Brinkman is the author of Blasphemy and Larceny in Lankhmar, and has written for DCC, DCC Lankhmar, DCC Dying Earth, MCC, and Fifth Edition Fantasy. He is the husband of ENnie award winning podcaster Jen Brinkman, and a tax professional, but he’s also been a stable hand, swordsman, bouncer, fire-breather, and professional pirate. Having played RPGs since the days when everything was digest-sized and beige, Bob delights in writing adventures where a shadow of the past darkens the present. In his spare time Bob does things like record the G.G. Joe theme song and run the annual Cyborg Commando tournament at Gary Con. He and his wife live with their four cats: Asimov, Etta, Harlan, and Vance.
Alasdair Cunningham has been playing role-playing games and their ilk for more than thirty years. Alasdair is a longtime writer for GCT Studios and has written for Chaosium and several other role-playing game publishers over the years. Born in Scotland but raised in South Africa, he resides in majestic Cape Town with his family where he spends his days surrounded by books, hordes of unpainted miniatures, and mounds of dice. He writes in a garden shed with a view of Table Mountain.
Eric Daum has been involved in gaming as a major part of his life since older cousins sat him down at age ten with the D&D Red Box. His deep connection to role playing continues to fuel his creative passions including art, writing, worldbuilding, and music-making. His guiding principle for adventure design is this: it’s the game that brings people together but it’s the story that keeps them there.
Tim Deschene got his start in gaming in 1983 when his dad bought him Strongheart and Warduke figures. Since then he has shown a proclivity for wearing armor exclusively on one side of his body. He is publishing zines for DCC and other old school games, as well as writing conversions of OSR adventures to DCC. He lives in Rhode Island with his wife, two daughters, and their pets Lulu and Prismo.
Marzio Muscedere began gaming in the fourth grade when his best friend landed the D&D red box. And yet, despite many a year spent gaming, things that should not have been forgotten were lost. And for time uncounted the hobby passed from his knowledge. Until, as chance would have it, DCC emerged, and like the poisonous gleam of a forbidden jewel enticed him back into the hobby. Since then he has been the honored recipient of the Rodneys Design Award and has authored adventures for Goodman Games and Purple Duck Games. When Marzio is not locked away in his scriptorium he can be found shuttling his children to sporting events or in the ring training and coaching boxing.
Terry Olson had his first foray into the arcane with Holmes the Blue. For two-score years after those studies, he’s practiced skullduggery, alley-bashing, and patron-pleasing in various librams, labyrinths, and unmentionable libido…but still hasn’t found the right blend of white and black magic. As an agent for Goodman Games, he’s traveled to the Purple Planet, Trapsylvania, Nehwon, Barako, and places where even Ningauble is forbidden. When he isn’t mercilessly slaying PCs who dare to challenge his tournament encounters, Terry designs spinning magnetic disks that reside in clouds and act as storage for memories, grimoires, and things beyond his ken. He enjoys wining, dining, and watching movies with his wife and discusses adventure design with his canine and feline familiars, Dixie and Venki.
Thorin “SonOvThrain” Thompson is a Bibliophile, Cat-Lord, Word-smith, and Wizard! He has always and forever shall be a big ol’ nerd! Growing up in his father’s comic shop, he was molded at a young age by the arcane energy found within all tabletop RPGs, but it was the discovery of DCC RPG that allowed that magic to blossom! Now as the owner/writer of Owl Knight Publishing he seeks to make his mark! When not slaying demons upon the rim of the multi-verse, Thorin can be found on set, working on a multitude of television shows/movies, or enjoying a quite night of reading with a fine bourbon and a sleepy cat companion.

updates.update_content:
Hi everyone,
Just a short update to let you know we expect fulfillment to happen in September. Now that all proofs have been approved, we have received the shipping schedule from the printer. Based on that, we think fulfillment should be complete by end of September. Mark it on your calendars!
In the meantime, we should receive advance copies of the print run by early July. We'll post photos as soon as we have them!

Hi everyone,
Printer proofs for Greatest Thieves in Lankhmar are complete and approved!
We just approved the last couple items. The first is the box. It looks great, as you can see here:

Hi everyone,
We're in the midst of a big proofing exercise with the printer, so I thought I would show you some pictures and give you an update. The fun part of this update is that we are going far beyond what was originally promised. The Greatest Thieves in Lankhmar is an epic adventure filled with a number of unique mechanics and clever puzzles. We are leveraging the elements of a boxed set to provide props you can use in-game to bring these encounters to life. In a way we're going back to those early TSR days where the line between "RPG" and "board game" wasn't quite so stark as it is right now.

Hello, Lankhmarts!
Great news: Greatest Thieves in Lankhmar is off to the printer!
Thanks for all your comments on the proofreader PDFs. We've corrected all the edits you caught. We've also made a couple upgrades. We're going to print some of the map tiles on perforated card stock, which should sit nicely on the map. And speaking of maps...specifically, this map...

Hello everyone!
We hope you're all enjoying the PDF of The Greatest Thieves in Lankhmar. We will soon be preparing the files for the printer. If you have spotted any typographical errors that we should fix in the PDF, now is the time to tell us! Please use our Stomp the Typo tool to submit any edits. If you do have any edits, please send them in by this weekend. Then we'll do one final pass and get everything ready for the printer!
DCC Kickstarters for Zinequest

Hi everyone!
You have PDFs! The proofreader edition of Greatest Thieves in Lankhmar is now available for download in BackerKit. Please download and let us know your comments!
By "proofreader edition," we mean this: You're getting the print-ready layout which we have edited and proofread extensively. However, no matter how many times we look at it, some astute fan always notices something we missed. In order to ensure that the printed product is perfect, we post the proofreader PDF first. We would love to hear your feedback. If you find any silly typos that escaped our notice, please tell us! We will incorporate your feedback before we send to print.

campaign.story:
By the pricking of my thumbs, something wicked this way comes...
Rough Cover Image by Chris Arendt
Welcome to our second Zinequest entry and 3rd Kickstarter Campaign! This year we are aiming at converting our Gamers & Grognards Octhorrorfest material into an Old-School Essentials compatible zine! This will include several of the classic articles and a few new ones, cleaned up and in line with OSE! Along with that, we will be bringing back our previous stable of artists to give you new and ghoulishly delightful art, as well as some new faces! So, what are we including in the material at the get go?
The Witch - New OSE Class
New spells for the Witch
Ritual Magic Rules for the Witch and existing spell casters
The Witch Hunter - New OSE Class
Blobs - New Monster
Horla - New Monster (featured in Hidden Hand of the Horla)
The Elder Sign: Turning the Outer Dark
Possession, Obsession and Exorcism Rules
Curing Vampirism
In addition to these, if we fund, stretch goals will be added for new material. Further more, you will notice we have a limited number of spots open for the "I Dig Monster Movies" tier. At this level, you can request a full write up of your favorite movie monster. This can be a horror/monster movie monster, or any creature from an appropriate B-rated flick. If you back at the "I Dig Monster Movies" tier, you will be able to suggest exactly what you think the creature should be able to do, based upon the film it is featured in. Each monster will be illustrated as well. What you pay for at this level is the writing, editing and art for the creature you would like to see brought to OSE. Obviously we cannot violate IP, so if you want "Michael Myers" we might be able to settle on creating a "Masked Eternal Killer."
Zines will be printed on the same high quality paper as our previous zines, with an orange cardstock cover.
Our Artists:
Diogo Nogueira
Diogo Nogueira is the owner of Old Skull Publishing, Diogo has published Sharp Swords & Sinister Spells, Solar Blades & Cosmic Spells and Dark Streets & Darker Secrets, amongst other games. He has also provided illustrations for such games as Astonishing Swordsmen and Sorcerers of Hyperborea and Old-School Essentials.
 Old Skulling 
 Old Skull On DriveThruRPG 
 Diogo's Art 
Stacie Joy
Stacie comes from a long line of moon people and there she resides in her ancestral home among the stars. On earth undercover she takes the human form of Jamie Hewlett’s Tank Girl - exploding evil-doers and jaywalkers alike whenever she damn well feels like it. Most days you can find her stumbling around Metro-Detroit where she spends her days tattooing on people and teaching piano when she’s not chained up in the basements of Appendix N Entertainment drawing up all that good stuff for you fine people to look at.
 Stacie Joy's art. Previous backers will notice some familiar pieces. 
Clayton Williams
Fantastic artist, friend and creator of the Lizardman piece featured in the "Original Edition Compatibility Logo." Hailing from Lansing, MI, Clayton is also a long time contributor to the Gongfarmer's Almanac. Appendix N Entertainment tries to not chain Clayton up in our basements.
 Clayton's Art 
 The Gongfarmer's Almanac 
 Chris Arendt 
My good friend, member of my gaming group, sometimes collaborator and my personal tattoo artist. They reside in the Detroit area of Michigan where they are working hard to become the Dinosaur Tattooist. They are the creator of the Gamers & Grognards logo. Also responsible for that sweet, sweet cover image above. We can't ever seem to find Chris to chain them to the work tables in the basements.
  Chris's Art at Science Fiction Is Now 
Denis McCarthy
Denis McCarthy has been doing old school linework art for the OSR since 2015,
 And his work has been seen in The Manor,  BlueHolme Journeymanne Rules, an assortment of products for Blood & Treasure 2nd edition including the Nod zine by John M.Stater, Gabor Lux’ Castle Xyntillan and the last several issues of Echoes from Fomalhault.  He was greatly influenced by David Trampier, Russ Nicholson, and David C. Sutherland III.

Denis's Art 
 Denis's Blog 
 Stretch Goals:
$2000 - New Race as Class and Advanced Race
The Pump-kin, a magically created species. Created to be golem like servitors, they gained sentience are are now a species of their own. The Pumpkin folk are misunderstood, and feared by many many folk as monsters, but truly just seek acceptance. 
$2250 - Jack-O-Lantern Article
This article will detail Jack-O-Lantern folk and ritual magic and how to use it in game.
$2500 - Samhain and Hallows - Lore and Rules For Your Campaign
The lore surrounding the "night when the veil between worlds is thinnest, and using this night in your games.

campaign.story:
The Salty Funnel is a 0-level adventure compatible with the DCC RPG. It will be an 8.5x11" format delivered in PDF. The expected page count is 25-32. Printed rewards for Real-Life Swabbie and Real-Life Pirate Player rewards will be 8.5x11" printed format with notes by the game runner and signatures of the 2 Old Guys and the players if they so choose to sign it. OK, on to the fun!
Compatible with DCC RPG
 We're on a Boat!
Captain Guido: "Ain't never met a paying customer I didn't like. So what if their faces were hidden in the cowls of purple robes with weird gold lettering around the cuffs and hem. Sure, maybe a tentacle slithered out of one of those cowls...but their coin passed the bite test, so I took it, and their smelly, slimy crates."
Mr. Skubagai, First Mate: "If the Cap'n had asked, me, I'd have told him that taking on cargo of an illicit nature with a ship full of landlubbers was a bad idea, but when's he ever consult his first mate? And, why are all those crates leaking some sort of ichor?"
Quartermaser Warklaw: "You even sail, bro?"
Captain: "Yes. I mean, I did just win this ship in a card game from a guy in a cape..."
Big Booty Boat by Domille's Wondrous Works. Used with permission.
 We've sailed! Well, not a project via Kickstarter...
A Barnacle-Laden Salty Funnel is a twist on nautical adventure themes. We'll forego all the Aye Mateys and Avast Ye Scurvy Dogs! This is the first in what we hope becomes a series of funnels we produce that have a multi-theme angle to them. We filled 3 Occupations tables (Christophor said that's a pain in the @ss but he's now a master of medieval jobs), took three standard nautical themes and then twisted them into a single product. This gives better replayability as well as some options in each play through. Choose from a cargo hold full of soon-to-be-slaves, a brig full of criminals, or a ballroom full of pompous a... elites.
 The Themes
Prison Transport
After a rather hurried and unpleasant trial, you were jailed, trussed up like a pig going to slaughter and then carted off to the docks.
Yes, you can guess the rest. Stripped of gear, slapped in a cage, deprived of food and drink... blah, blah, blah.
Slave Trader
As soon as you wake, you wish you hadn’t. There's crusted blood on your face and a knot on the side of your head. On top of that, the ground keeps moving to and fro making you want to heave up anything that might remain in your stomach.
The really unfortunately thing is, they're chained to the floorboards!
High Society
"A gilded invitation to take a jaunty three-hour tour with the rest of society's elite? It's all about hobnobbing with the snobbiest so I piled on my finest finery and my excessively ornate accoutrements..." 
Yeah, that was always going to end badly. Three-hour tour? Just asking for trouble!
Then, of course, the ship sinks. Unfortunately, for them, there's a band of armed growling guards/savage slavers/recalcitrant retainers in their way.
Quartermaster Warklaw: “But little did they know escaping the frigid waters of the sinking ship was the least of their problems...”
Indeed. Because, it's Worse. Something Just Moved Past My Leg...
When Tentacles Attack!
Sure, more Star Wars references than you can throw a belaying pin at along with some other pop culture riffs. Reading an adventure as the Judge shouldn't be a mindless, dry thing.
If players survive thus far, then they get to...
Float Away with the Rest of the Garbage!
But we didn't stop there. In scene 3 we included another crazy plot twist that we think everyone will enjoy as it embraces the weirdness of the DCC RPG mindset... pirates! Oh? Not weird you say? Pirates from the Aether! 
That enormous, unknown space between the orbs of reality... is traveled by pirates. Pirates who have literally decimated an island when their massive Aethership crashed into it making it a hellscape crater, but what other choice have the PCs got? Plus, these squid-faced creatures have probably taken over some of their friends and are using them as new crew members. The question then becomes? Save them, or loot their corpses for wondrous, shiny, magical contraptions?
First Mate: "Wait, is this like in Aliens where their stomachs explode?"
Captain: "No, more like Scanners, where it's their heads that explode..."
Quartermaster: "Gross, I'm going to have to clean that up, aren't I?"
First Mate: "Not it!"
Captain: "Have one of the other crew do it."
Quartermaster: "There is no other crew."
Captain: "Oh, well... Not it!"
Quartermaster: "Dammit."
Until, finally, they're washed ashore. 
Commissioned art by Rachel Maduro. The Aether Raider.
 Unknown: "I'm not saying it was aliens... but it was ALIENS!"
Why Kickstarter
We are using this Kickstarter as a way to generate some "seed capital" so that we can create bigger, better products in the future. A Barnacle-Laden Salty Funnel is already written and we're taking the campaign time to fine tune, playtest, and get art in place. We're not skimping on the details, but we are aiming for a low cost point for backers yet have to ensure we can cover the expenses in the end. If things go extremely well we've got some simple, yet interesting stretch goals in the works to thank our backers for getting 2OG off the ground. The goal is a nearly all-digital campaign, but there are some tiers with a few slots for physical rewards, especially if you're heading to Gary Con XII
Combined, Christophor & Michael have over 50 years of tabletop gaming experience. Christophor is teaching the next generation of gamers already via his Kids' D&D sessions in Milwaukee and some of the adventures we will release were first played by them. See our other events at Gary Con XII, and Gen Con 2020. Plus, Christophor is Judging for Goodman Games tournament at Gen Con this year, so he might kill your characters a few times by 2021.
The Stats
4 New Occupation Tables
3 New Weapons
4 New Creatures
24 new items
Nautical themed character sheets
Dozens of witty computer interjections
High resolution maps for VTT or personal printing
The Team
Art
Warklaw - Maps, character sheets, other
Rachel Maduro - Aether Raiders, other
Domille - Ship maps
AstralArts - judge's screen
Writing
 Christophor Rick
Michael Spredemann
Stretch Goals for The Salty Funnel
 $750 - UNLOCKED - Nautical themed character sheets (2 variants!) We already started working on these and have some options in the works. These will include a full-page character sheet and a traditional 4-per-sheet DCC 0-level character sheet.
Character sheet preview.
UNLOCKED $900 - NEW THEME - A new Pirate crew! Play beside, or as, Captain Guido, 1st Mate Skubagai and Quartermaster Warklaw. The theme will include a new occupation table, new story content and pre-generated characters for the three top officers which can be used as PCs, or as noteworthy NPCs for the other themes.
We couldn't actually do a nautical adventure with multiple themes and NOT have actual pirates, could we? I mean, we were going to try, but well... the outpouring of support and backing changed that. 
UNLOCKED $1000 - New Handcrafted Character Sheet - Warklaw is a master of the visual arts whereas I am a master of the written word...or at least a really experienced journeyman. When we started discussing character sheets he whipped up some amazing art and we decided that his version would be its own goal...because it's pretty damned amazing. 
Warklaw's Fabulous Handcrafted Character Sheet (rough sketch sneak peek)
UNLOCKED $1100 - Two New sea creatures Sometimes, adventures focus on adversity and obstacles. After all,  struggle is the essence of drama and adventure. However, there are also  super cool things that could show up or happen that are good for the  players. With this stretch goal we are doing both. We'll add in two new  sea creatures, one that is potentially helpful and one that is  potentially deadly. 
UNLOCKED $1200 OR 100 FOLLOWERS ON TWITTER OR FACEBOOK - Print on Demand After much discussion, and hand wringing and research we have decided that Print on Demand is something that we are prepared to offer. Well, not exactly prepared, but we can't learn if we don't do it. Therefore, at $1200 (or the new social media goal) we will open up ways to join the POD... you know, like a group of whales? ARRR! 
UNLOCKED $1300 - High Resolution Maps for VTT or Personal Printing While some play in person, others play online. We're trying to cater to  as many as we can. That said, we will include high resolution maps so  they can be dropped into popular online TTRPG platforms and still look  good and remain usable. This also means they'll be good for printing on  your own if you so choose. These will be packaged in a separate PDF and  come with all PDF tiers. There will not be a POD option for these maps.  We have a large stack of DCC modules and most of them just offer inline  maps. We wanted to make sure they we gave more options in this area as  recreating the maps and making them look good can be time consuming for  already busy Judges.
UNLOCKED $1500 A Collection of Sea Shanties for Backers We previously mentioned something about sea shanties. Well, we have a musically talented friend who is whipping up some bawdy sea shanties. We don't have tons of information as of yet, but we are striving to nail down some details before we cross the next stretch goal. This unlocks at $1500.
UNLOCKED $1750 Item & Creature Cards The items and creatures in the Salty Funnel will be broken out into easy to manage reference cards. These can be used to better organize while running the game. 
UNLOCKED $2000 Judge's Screen This screen will display an epic scene painted by a Milwaukee area artist specifically for The Salty Funnel and 2 OG Games. The judge's side will feature useful tables, and information as one would expect. We are looking into POD options for this which might just be an early access, discount price thing instead of a new reward tier.
UNLOCKED $2250 Two New Player Classes Two new classes that tie directly into the story, items and creatures in the Salty Funnel. Totally unique and aimed at continuing the fun beyond Level 0.
UNLOCKED $2500 Additional Mini Adventure Speaking of beyond Level 0! A mini Level 1 adventure that picks up right where your group might have left off at the end of the Salty Funnel. Just as a way to get your campaign moving from the end of the Funnel out into the wide open world around you.
You overachiever!
Holy cats! You're still reading? Did you get repetitive stress syndrome of your mouse finger scrolling this far down? Well, there's nothing to see down here... OK, there is!
Collectively, Christophor and Michael have backed over 350 projects on Kickstarter and help support the community as much as they can. It helps create a diverse ecosystem of game-expanding content and drives the hobby they both love toward an ever-brighter future.
The Small Print
Rules Set: DCC RPG, an OGL system that cross-breeds Appendix N with a streamlined version of 3E.
Support: Goodman Games supports DCC RPG with an extensive line of adventure modules and select other materials.
This product is based upon the Dungeon Crawl Classics Role Playing Game, published by Goodman Games. This product is published under license. Dungeon Crawl Classics and DCC RPG are trademarks of Goodman Games. All rights reserved. For additional  information, visit www.goodman-games.com or contact  info@goodman-games.com
campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
Being a new publisher there are many pitfalls that we have to avoid. With that in mind we decided this would be a digital only campaign. While there are certain levels that have a physical component to them, it is something that we can arrange ourselves and in short order. Eleven short adventures each suitable for one night's play!
Contains 11 new monsters and 33 Further Adventure™ hooks to inspire busy DMs with new adventure once the quest is complete.  These side quests are perfect while traveling in new areas or transitioning between your own stories. They can be played as-is, or pulled apart to merge seamlessly in your own adventures.
Acolyte
Levels 1-2. An old Acolyte friend needs help battling the undead and coming into his own power. But if you fail, there may be dire consequences.
Curse Of The Ice Mage
Levels 5-6. The sudden arrival of a massive winter storm midsummer leads the townsfolk to seek the party's help.
Escape From The Roaring Mines
Levels 4-5. Taking a shortcut through a cursed mine, the party is pursued by a sinister entity. A great side quest when travelling through mountainous areas.
Fane Of Madness
Level 5-6. A cave-in leads your party into a sidequest suitable for any Urban/Town setting. Great for leading the party into a sewer adventure.
Journey To The Summit Of Mount Gellid
Level 5-6. An adventure where the party seeks to slay a white dragon, including several paths and options.
Level 0 Encounters
Level 0. A 5e mechanic and adventure for playing level 0 characters. New opportunities to roleplay your character backgrounds, or reminisce about how your character became an adventurer.
Murder At The Dour Dryad
Any Level. A non-combat murder mystery. Help an inexperienced city watchman investigate a grisly murder with roleplay and skill challenges.
Nyx's Wild Hunt
Levels 4-5. The party runs afoul of a dark goddess' minions, a great sidequest or recurring group of foes.
Rite Of Passage
Levels 1-3. The party must participate in a ritual hunt, acting rite of passage, and feed a barbarian clan. Perfect to level a party of four from Level 1 to Level 2.
Sundering of the Crystal Staff
Play As Monsters! When the necromancer's staff is broken, a party of undead become self aware. Play as undead and choose to side with your former master, or the  paladin order assaulting his tower.
The Tomb Of The Sorcerer Thane
Levels 5-6. The party must track a missing child into the tomb of an undead sorcerer.
Newly revised in Print!
The Side Quest bundle will have revised content, updated for print.
Already own the Side Quest Bundle PDF?
You will receive a free copy of the revised PDF.

campaign.story:
To all of our wonderful Midderlands backers:
We’re all aware of the impact that the virus is having on Kickstarter fundings, and unfortunately we’ve come to the point where we’ve decided to postpone Midderlands so we can do it better justice later on. The support you’ve all shown for the project has been tremendous, and rest assured that the Midderlands will be back on Kickstarter at some point in the future! But we’d rather have that happen when we’ll be offering stretch goals after day one rather than worrying whether the project will fund at all. So we will definitely have the Midderlands back again, but for the time being we’re going to cancel this Kickstarter so we can start again later.
Zach Glazar
Necromancer Games
A message from Glynn:
It is with a heavy heart that we delay this Kickstarter, but it is the right thing to do at this time. We want everyone to take care of themselves and their loved ones as their number one priority.
To those that have pledged to the project so far, we really appreciate your enthusiasm and support and promise to get this book to you in the future.  Fear not, we shall return!
Please stay safe, follow the advice, and thank you!
Glynn
The Midderlands
A green-hued, dark-fantasy setting and bestiary set in a twisted middle-England.
Situated in the middle of Havenland is an area known by the ancestors as the Middle Havenlands. They don’t use that name much anymore, preferring to talk lazily, and skip letters. In strange accents, often misheard and little understood by those outside of the central region - they call it ‘The Midderlands’, and themselves ‘Midfolk’ or ‘Midderlanders’.
Everywhere though, the Midderlands is tainted by a green-tinged menace that rises from ‘Middergloom’, the deep and mysterious realms beneath the surface. It affects nature and order. Sometimes subtly and sometimes catastrophically. Middergloom is often described as hell bathed in green fire and flames. Green-tinged, viscid slime; noxious, acrid vapours, and miasmas of hopelessness creep upwards from below. Amongst them, viridian-coloured demons, lime-green tentacles and other malachite horrors claw their way to the surface to wreak havoc. The Lords of the land are always working to keep things at bay. They fight endlessly as if holding back a torrent of despair.
Things stir in this viridian-hued landscape. Evil eyes blink and watch. Teeth and claws scratch and sharpen. Gaping maws slobber and drool.
All is not content in the Midderlands.
Final design subject to change.
THE MIDDERLANDS 5E BOOK INCLUDES:
Creatures
25 Fully-detailed creatures
Each creature provided with an NPC version.
Some creatures include rules for using as playable races.
A large poster hex map of The Midderlands
Detailed geographic setting information
29 Fixed hex descriptions
3 Random hex descriptions
16 Hamlets (5 mapped)
11 Small towns (3 mapped)
8 Large towns (5 mapped)
25 Points of interest
Information on currency, effects of gloomium, gods, and the dialect.
New layout and many pieces of new artwork
New cartography from ENnie Award-winning cartographer, Glynn Seal.
Adventure
1 Short introductory adventure
6 Adventure ideas
Loads of ‘game-juice’ to get your ideas flowing.
Oddities
4 Flora
13 Fauna (including birds, fish, bugs, and more.)
5 Spells
13 Items
Appendices
Tables of names
Tables of ‘Crap You Find On Midfolk’
 Free Midderlands Taster <-- click here for 8 pages of the Midderlands
The Midderlands 5e
The Midderlands is an award-winning, weird world-setting for fifth edition (D&D). It’s late middle ages/Tudor England seen through a looking glass, filled with strange creatures, insidious threats, and the color green. It’s edgy, it’s twisted, and the first thing you should expect is the last thing you’d expect. Looking for a 5e setting completely different from anything you’ve seen before? You’ve found it – now let’s see if you can survive it…
Sample image of The Midderlands 5e cover
Words from the Author
The Midderlands exists because of a series of fortunate thoughts.
It was mid-late 2016 and often I would go around to my partner’s house on the evenings and whilst she sat on the sofa watching the television, I doodled the heads of strange creatures in side profile.
I had no plan for these doodles, but I had a sketchbook and I wanted to fill quite a lot of it. As I doodled, I imagined that these creatures might live in the surrounding lands where I lived. That gave them much more life. I then thought I could create a book of creatures with a little about where they live and what they do.
Then I figured that rather than living in the land where I do now, why not an alternate version of where I live. It would be a bit weirder, darker, gloomier. I wanted something that made the land the way it did. That’s when Gloomium became a thing.
The locations would be inspired by the real world, but twisted and green-tinged, so I needed a map. I made an alternative version and that’s when I decided this was a game setting.
Map of the Midderlands
The creation of the initial setting book for old school games – the 5E version of which is being crowdfunded here – spawned another book which covered the rest of the United Kingdom, and then a further book which focused on the setting’s version of London, Great Lunden.
Sample page from The Midderlands 5e
I have been amazed with its success and wanted to bring a version of the original to the 5E audience, so they too could enjoy wandering its twisted locales and encounter its unusual creatures. I just wasn’t sure how to achieve it.
Luckily, the kindly amphibians at Necromancer Games came to the rescue and we are now in a great position to bring a new version of the setting to you. My hands will be heavily involved in new and updated artwork and maps and a new layout.
This is going to be exciting and you won’t want to miss out.
—Glynn 
Note: See even more of Glynn's work or purchase a copy of the Original Swords & Wizardry Midderlands titles by going to the MonkeyBlood Design & Publishing website at the link below.
https://monkeyblooddesign.co.uk/


Mouselings will scurry home with a PDF copy of the Midderlands and its fabulous map.
Short-horned Ratdogs get a nice chew toy for their lair—a hardcover copy of the 5e version of the Midderlands and a folded poster map—as well as a PDF copy of both. These books will be upgraded as we hit stretch goals.
 The mighty Oorgthrax get a copy of the KickStarter exclusive collector's edition Midderlands book.  We're planning a linen-like cover embossed on the spine and front cover with foil. In green of course. The book comes with a folded poster map and the PDF version of both. These books will be upgraded as we hit stretch goals.  
 The Four-eyed Grabbers grab it all! A great way to use your tax return! One copy of the KickStarter exclusive collector's edition book, one copy of the standard hardcover version, and two copies of the poster map (that's one physical item for each eye). The Grabber also gets a PDF copy of the book and map. These books will be upgraded as we hit stretch goals.
$12,000 FUNDED!
$15,000 Sewn in ribbons in all books
$20,000 Colored head & tail bands in all books
$??? Printed endpapers in all books
$??? Physical bookmark added to each book
Physical add-ons available with physical pledge levels only. Extra standard edition Midderlands 5e books and maps will be available during the checkout phase of fulfillment at the Frog God Games website. Collector's edition books will not be available after the Kickstarter ends.  Do not add extra money for these items until that time.
Standard Hardcover + Map: $40
Additional Map only: $7
Follow the Conversation on Necromancer Games Social Media
Twitter: https://twitter.com/NecroG_ames
Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/Necromancer-Games-106541330746877
Shipping and Post-Project Changes
Shipping is NOT included in the pledge and is NOT collected on KICKSTARTER. It will be charged right before the rewards are shipped on our web page.
Some changes from our previous Kickstarter projects
1. We will NOT be using a pledge manager (like Backerkit) for this project. All pledges are locked when the project ends; we will not have a method to change your pledge reward after the project closes. You will however be able to purchase additional add-ons when you pay shipping (see below). The collector's book will not be available as an add-on.
2. We will not be charging shipping until your rewards are packed. This leaves out guesswork and allows for maximum flexibility in selecting the carrier and packaging material for your reward.
3. This project’s rewards will all be shipped priority mail (or equivalent) to domestic and international backers.
Note to international backers
We continue to see cost increases and damage increases on overseas shipping. We cannot do anything about this. Likewise, some countries charge VAT tax or other fees to our customers on receipt. We cannot fraudulently lie about the value of materials we mail out. We have considered not selling books and games overseas due to the complaints about postage. That being said, we have a number of long term customers that we want to be able to receive our books if they do not mind paying the associated costs. However, we cannot give an honest shipping quote until we charge shipping because we just do not know the costs for future deliveries in every country. Be aware the overseas postage costs are not for the faint of heart!
Refunds and replacements
We will happily ship your game anywhere you indicate on your Kickstarter survey provided that regular service is available from the USA (e.g., not to nations subject to trade embargoes or to other planets). If your rewards are damaged or missing after shipment we will replace the damaged or missing items.  However, we will NOT process refunds for unshipped items.
campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
Necromancer Games is financially backed and owned by Frog God Games. Frog God staff will get this done. Frog God Games has been in business since 2010, and has fulfilled numerous (23!) Kickstarter programs in the past. As with any crowdfunding program, the time-lapse between payment and delivery of a final product is subject to various risks, including the failure of a supplier, damage in shipment, disruptions within a company, invasions by carnivorous space rabbits and changes in the prices of materials and shipping. Experience gained over a number of projects makes us confident that we have contingency plans for the ordinary, foreseeable issues that might arise.

In addition to regular risks, due to the Coronavirus, we could have supply chain delays. We do not anticipate major issues with this, but the elder plague gods may have different ideas.
Learn about accountability on Kickstarter

campaign.story:
After two years of intensive design and development, we’re excited to announce Autarch’s ninth Kickstarter project: Ascendant™, a new superpowered role-playing game of infinite possibilities.    
Simulating a Comic Book World  
Comic book RPGs tend to be sub-divided into “descriptor-based” and “effect-based” games. “Bolt of Fire” is a descriptor, while “Ranged Attack that deals 50 points of damage to one target” is an effect. A descriptor-based game prioritizes the descriptor over the effects. An effect-based game prioritizes the effects over the descriptor.
Ascendant strives to be neither a descriptor-based nor effect-based game. It is, rather, a physics-based game. The game mechanics are intended to be the physics engine of the game world. Powers have both descriptors and effects. Some effects are precluded by the logic of the descriptor, and some descriptors inevitably entail certain effects. The mechanics are elaborate and detailed (as in an effect-based game) but they are also broad and universalized (as in a descriptor-based game). Players are expected and encouraged to use their powers in whatever manner makes sense within the physics of a comic-book world, but not in ways that don’t make sense.
If a descriptor-based system aims to let players experience a comic-book story, and an effect-based system aims to let players play a superhero game, our physics-based system aims to let players simulate a comic book world. To do so, we have created logarithmic chart-based universal mechanics, a style of design that has not been widely used in the last two decades, but which will be instantly familiar to fans of the classic FASERIP and MEGS RPGs from the 1980s.  
Learning the Game  
The easiest way to learn about Ascendant is to get walked through a character stat block. Below is the stat block for Aurora. Previously a D-grade celebrity from a TV  reality show, her ambition to be a dazzling star in the spotlight was granted…sort of… when she manifested the ability to control and generate light. Now she is one of the most famous ascendants in the world, with brand sponsorships from beauty and fashion companies, her own press team, and a prestigious membership in the Star-Spangled Squadron, America’s premier team of crimefighting ascendants.   
Up at the top you can see Aurora's Character Points, Power Limit, and Challenge Rating. Character Points (CP) are used to construct characters. An average human has 200 CP. A trained soldier has 240 CP. An exceptionally impressive, formidable and renowned human in the real world has 400 CP.  Every 80 CP represents an approximate doubling of the character’s competency across all capabilities. With 940 Character Points, Aurora is one of the 20 most powerful superhumans in the world. Power Limit constrains how  characters can allocate their CP and is analogous to class level in a D20 RPG. Challenge Rating shows how powerful a character is relative to a trained soldier. Aurora can defeat 500 US infantry simultaneously - she's a tough woman.  
Over on the right, below her image, you'll see Aurora's Primary Attributes: Might (MIG), Agility (AGI), Valor (VAL), Resolve (RES), Insight (INS), and Charisma (CHA). Each of these Primary Attributes are rated in Supermetric Points (SP). SP are logarithmic; each additional one SP has a value equal to double the amount of the previous SP.  Ordinary people have 3 SPs in each of their Primary Attributes, and the most impressive humans typically have no more than 5 SP in any Primary Attribute. With 7 SPs of Agility, Aurora is four times more agile than an Olympic athlete. With 12 SPs of Charisma, Aurora is 500 times more magnetic and alluring than any ordinary person.
To the left of the Primary Attributes are Aurora's Secondary Attributes, which rate factors like Initiative, Passive Spotting Range, Height, Income, and more. With a Flight Speed of 14 SPs, Aurora can fly at Mach 24!
Below the Variable Attributes we list Aurora's Powers. Her most important Power is Agile Light Control. Light Control is a pre-defined Power Set that allows her to emulate many other powers.  (The rules let you build your own power sets if you want, yes!)   
The word Agile in front of Light Control is a modifier that changes how the power works. In this case, it means that Aurora uses her Light Control in conjunction with her Agility rather than her Insight. Between Powers, Power Sets, and Modifiers, there are infinite possibilities available to make virtually any character you can imagine.
Below Powers we've listed Aurora's Skills. Skills can be substituted for Primary Attributes for specific purposes. For instance, Aurora has 14 SPs of Aerial Combat. If she's the target of a ranged attack while she's flying, she can substitute her Aerial Combat score for her Agility score, making her much harder to hit. 
Below the Primary Attributes, you can see Aurora's Perks and Drawbacks. Perks function similarly to Feats in a D20 RPG. Some of the most important Perks are the Combat Maneuvers, which allow you to trade damage for accuracy and vice versa. Aurora's got two Combat Maneuvers as well as a host of other Perks related to her status as a celebrity member of the elite Star-Spangled Squadron.
Aurora has a number of minor Drawbacks such as her Code of Honor ("always be fabulous") as well as one very serious Drawback called a Vulnerable State. A Vulnerable State models all the situations that can result in heroes becoming weaker or losing their powers. Exposed to meteorites from your homeworld? Caught out of your powered armor? Forgot to recharge your power ring? Not angry enough to turn green? All modeled with Vulnerable State. Aurora's Vulnerable State is that all of her powers are based on her egoistic desire to be a star; if she's ever reduced to 0 Determination, she gets depressed, loses her superpowers, and acquires a host of flaws. 
Speaking of Determination, that's one of the game's Variable Attributes. The other one is Health, and both are listed near the top of the sheet. These are like Hit Points in a D20 Game. Unlike the other Attributes, Variable Attributes aren't rated in SP, just in raw numbers, so that when you deal and take damage it's all scaled correctly.
As for how the game itself works, it's so easy even a 200-CP ordinary human can play it! Anytime you want to make an Action, you choose your Action Value (AV) and then subtract the Difficulty Value (DV) to yield a Resolution Value (RV). You then roll 1d100 on the Challenge Action Resolution Table, or CHART, to see your Color Result. The CHART is carefully structured so that the expected values for any AV versus any RV are exactly what they ought to be, given the logarithmic nature of the Attributes.  (It's pretty slick if you like math and we'll update on this in more detail later.)   
Let's simulate Aurora shooting a Thermal Blast at the blindsighted assassin Helen Killer. Down at the bottom of her sheet, we've listed Aurora's Attacks. Each Attack has an Action Value and a Base Damage. If Aurora fires a Thermal Blast at Helen Killer, her AV for the Attack is 14 SPs and her Base Damage is 256. Her DV for the Attack is Helen's Combat Sense, which happens to be 13 SPs. That gives Aurora an RV of 14 - 13 = +1 on the CHART. Let's say her player rolls a 32. Scanning across the "1" row of the RV (Attack) column, we see that 32 falls into the Yellow range, so Aurora has scored a Yellow result on her Attack. 
When you score a Green result when making an Attack, you deal Base Damage, while Yellow, Orange, and Red results increase damage by a factor of 2, 4, or 8. Since Aurora scored a Yellow result she deals 512 points of Damage to Helen Killer. Helen now gets to  apply Protection like Forcefield or Invulnerability, then Roll With the Attack to reduce Damage in exchange for taking on various Conditions like "Dazed" or "Staggered".
We'll discuss the rules more in future updates but if you want more details, be sure to check out the sneak preview of the game’s first two chapters at the link below!   
What if Superhumans Had Just Emerged?
Enough about rules. Let's talk about setting! Ascendant includes an optional campaign setting inspired by comics like Watchmen, The Boys, Squadron Supreme, The Authority, and Invincible. The world of Ascendant  doesn't begin to diverge from that of our real world until 2012, and the first superheroes don't go public until the Battle of Atlanta in 2018, meaning your player characters will be among the first superhumans to ever don tights and fight crime.  The setting is presented as an epistolary novel made up of leaked documents, transcripts, newspaper clippings, and emails that you can print out and give to your players - like this one.   
Of course, we also include statistics for all of the major characters and organizations presented in the backstory, too. If you're intrigued, be sure to download the sneak preview of the campaign setting by clicking on the image below.  (Art and layout not yet final!)   
The Art of Ascendant  
Comics are a visual medium and no comic book game should be without amazing illustrations. We’ve secured a team of top comic book artists to bring the world of Ascendant to life. Here's some samples of the artwork we've already commissioned. With your support, there'll be lots more!   
AIRBORNE faces STILETTO in a rooftop battle between hero and anti-hero
Hyperkinetic teleporter WARP confronts blindsighted assassin HELEN KILLER
The world's first (and only) ascended manatee, LEVITEE, visits NYC on his Goodwill Tour
AURORA of the Star-Spangled Squadron is greeted by adoring fans
Pledge Levels  
Are you ready to pledge? Choose your power level! When you back Ascendant you can choose to receive the 350-page rulebook in PDF, softcover, or hardcover format.   
*NEW To celebrate hitting our first stretch goal we have added a new Pledge Level called Vigilante + Sidekick ($30), which gets you all the stretch goals in PDF. In addition all reward levels above that will get all stretch goals in PDF, too.*
PLEASE NOTE  your pledge does NOT include the cost of shipping. We will collect the cost of shipping at the time of reward fulfillment by using a Pledge Manager.   Digital rewards will be delivered via DriveThruRPG. Physical rewards will be delivered via our U.S.-based fulfillment house. International backers, please be aware that international shipping from the U.S. is expensive and you will be responsible for import duties, taxes, and tariffs. If you want to minimize your shipping cost, we offer the Vigilante and Crimefighter pledge levels (PDF or POD coupon).
Stretch Goals
Hopefully this Kickstarter will go up, up, and away! If so, we stand ready with some amazing stretch goals. Paragon ($90) and higher tier backers will get ALL stretch goal products included with their pledge. Other backers can purchase stretch goal products as add-ons while supplies last.   
 Thank you for checking out Ascendant. We're super-excited to bring you the game!
campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
After two years of research and writing, Ascendant's rules are already complete, with more than 217,000 words of amazing content ready to be laid out and illustrated.

This is Autarch's ninth Kickstarter, and despite some occasional Herculean setbacks, we've never failed to deliver a great product to our backers. However, in our last Kickstarter, we suffered a six-month delay. The causes of the delay were twofold. First, we added some additional material via stretch goals that took time to write. Second, we committed to full color art but only had one artist. For this Kickstarter, none of our stretch goals will require delays for writing, and we've got a team of five artists on tap to handle the illustrations. 

Most of the rewards are digital and will be delivered via DriveThruRPG. For printed material, we use McNaughton & Gunn, a US-based publishing house, so the current disruptions to the global supply chain shouldn't have any effect on us. 

We're grateful for your interest, and hope to see you as a backer!
Learn about accountability on Kickstarter

campaign.story:
You are already a great Dungeon Master. You run a game really well.
What's the difference between a room and a chamber? What's the difference between a mausoleum, a sepulcher, and a crypt? Would disarming traps be more exciting if you understood how those complex mechanisms worked? What does a magic trap look like? What does a solar room look like and what's usually inside?
Do you think it would be exciting if a classic group of fantasy artists got together and drew pictures of all these artifices, deceptions, and dilemmas for you to use as reference at your table with your group?
I did.
What's in it?
Curious about the content? Check out the table of contents from the book. Want to see what's written? Back the project and read the art-free PDF that is available in the second backer update.
 In those sections there's information on different ways to describe dangers to the player characters, along with twists and turns, inspiring you to create your own rube goldberg mechanisms that the players can escape from. You already know how to make it fair and fun. 
The book is written and an art-free version will be available to backers now. But I'd like to get a book like this illustrated.
What are the details
This will be an approximately 200-page paperback. It will be lavishly illustrated. Behold.

Who's involved?
I reached out to Skullfungs, Karl Stjernberg who did the Beautiful cover to my first kickstarter, which delivered on time and to acclaim (over 1000 copies sold and a review score of 4.8) and he agreed to do the cover for this. I also need an editor, and the talented Sandor Gebei also agreed to come back and turn my text into something professional-like. 
Karl's Previous Cover

That's what the funding level of the Kickstarter covers. But I reached out to other people.
Marcin S (Perdition, Against the Darkmaster), James Shields, Russ Nicholson (A Warlock on Firetop Mountain, Fiend Folio), and Steve Crompton (Grimtooth's Traps) have all agreed to do illustrations for this project. I'm chuffed, right? I'm not the only person who thinks getting art from these artists would be amazing.
Stretch Goals
Now we have a chance to get more art from wonderful artists. This book is extensively illustrated—nearly every single one of the page spreads of the book is illustrated.  Take a look at the draft copy in backer update 2, and check out the space devoted to art in the layout. With the work of the people below, Artifices, Deceptions, and Dilemmas will be a portal to an ink-carved realm of fantasy and mystery!
Who am I?
I'm an independent writer and artist, who's been producing gaming and gaming-
related products for years. You've likely already read stuff I've written. My last kickstarter, On Downtime and Demesnes, funded on Kickstarter in hours and was released on time. People like it. My blog Hack & Slash has been popular for years; and since I've gone full time, my high-level module Eyrie of the Dread Eye has nothing but five-star reviews.
campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
This is my second Kickstarter, but the draft of the book is written, the layout is complete. I have finished products like this dozens of times, and consistently receive astounding 4.5+ star ratings on my products.

I've given myself more of a window this time, but I've worked with every single one of the artists (except Steve) before, and they've all turned in amazing work promptly. My expectation is that they will continue to be professional and produce on time. That said, Russ is very busy, which is why he requested a generous window. It is worth. 

I have a lot of experience working with DriveThruRPG to produce printed copies. I completed my last kickstarter on time. People received their copies on time.
I don't suffer from depression, and I am a productive person who is online frequently. I'm here to work. My previous kickstarter experience, my professional relationship with these artists, and my success at fulfillment using DriveThruRPG give me a great deal of confidence I can complete this project on time.
Learn about accountability on Kickstarter

campaign.story:
It’s the end of the world. It always rains. Rain beats against the walls. It seeps through the shutters. It pours off the mossy backs of the gargoyles. It turns streets into streams and rivers.
Teetering, damp towers lean against rotting townhouses thrown together in the ruins of a once gleaming city. Servants dash through storms on petty errands. Fireplaces sputter weakly, and spellbooks filled with moldy spells rot in spite of the protections lavished on them for their precious contents.
A VISITOR'S GUIDE TO THE RAINY CITY is a system-agnostic RPG zine offering a complete setting playset and toolkit for GMs and players alike to mine for your own games and campaign settings or drop into a campaign as is. Spice up your roleplaying with the weirdness, whimsy, and wickedness of the Rainy City - a doomed fantasy metropolis at the end of the world - where the wizards jealously guard their rotting magical tomes, the gargoyles are always watching, the thieves are on the prowl, and the rains never stop.
As a GM Playset & Toolkit
The VISITOR'S GUIDE is designed for busy GMs to mine for your own games and campaigns. Need a flavorful but dour neighborhood to drop into a city you're prepping? Then use the paranoid and cult-infested Levee Town. Need a strange NPC wizard for players to sell their ill-gotten loot to? Oculam the Oracular is your wizard; he already saw you coming! Need a weird urban location to toss in front of your players? Then look no further because Vengus Ult's Mushroom Library has just sprouted up in Old Town. Need a colorful folktale to flesh out your local village? Then Ware the Winder Man, who comes every Mid-Winder Night to enter your home and steal your breath. 
Break the VISITOR'S GUIDE down, mine it for gems, and use them as your own.  
As a Whole Setting
GMs can also use the VISITOR’S GUIDE as a complete, interconnected setting. The Rainy City can be dropped into the oceans of nearly any fantasy world, be found on the edges of the Elemental Plane of Water, or used as we use it -- as the last city left, where everyone and everything eventually washes up as world after world is destroyed by flood. Maybe it’s a place your regular characters pass through on their adventures. Maybe it’s a sort of Bermuda Triangle where they get stuck, for a while. Maybe it’s a pocket universe, maybe a dream, or even some sort of hell. If you can think of a use for a magic rich, rain-soaked city with an Age of Sail flavor that could house any sort of fantasy, you can drop the Rainy City into your campaign.
Take it, pair it with your favorite game, and make it your own. 
The Wizards of the Rainy City - sometimes mysterious, often menacing, but always weird!
Influences and Look
The Rainy City is the brainchild of Rich Forest, who has been thinking about, developing, and running game sessions in the Rainy City for more than fifteen years now. This is a passion project for Rich, and it shows in the vibrant and evocative details inherent in the Rainy City as a setting and playset.
The setting's influences are varied. The influence of Jack Vance’s Dying Earth books is obvious in the wizards, and we hope some of Pratchett’s warmth and good humor can be found as well. Many touches inspired by folklore (especially folklore of the sea), the history of great cities (especially London, which has a lot written about it in English), and history and fiction about piracy and the Age of Sail have informed the place. Every game system it has been used with has left its mark, from Big Eyes, Small Mouth, to classic D&D, The Fantasy Trip, Castle Falkenstein, Warhammer Fantasy Roleplay, Mythras, and 5th edition.  
The look of the zine evokes the style of an early modern European pamphlet. As such, we're using Fell Type fonts throughout, and the interior art by Bill Spytma is in a style he's developed that emulates the kind of woodcut art you can see in those old pamphlets. 
For a doomed city at the end of the world, the Rainy City is a vibrant, alive, and, well, weird place.
What's in the Zine?
What’s included in the zine? Detailed descriptions, notable NPCs, evocative locations, and capsule adventure hooks for:
 The Eight Main Districts of the City: Vagabond Bay, Old Town, Levee Town, The Sump, The Mids, Embassy Row, The Headlands, and The Tower Cliffs (with Maps!)
   The Peoples of the Rainy City, detailing some of the more exotic denizens of the city, such as Gargoyles, Ghouls, Gulls, Larvae, Mine Goblins, Mermaids, Ratkins, and Sump Boggies
   The Pirates of the Rainy City, including their floating pirate haven of Rickety
   The Guilds of the Rainy City, including spotlight focus on The Alchemists Guild, The Society of Thatch, and The Molten Men
   The Four Seasons of the Rainy City: The Rainy Season, The Windy Season, The Quiet, and Firelight, plus the traditions, customs, and holidays associated with each.
   The Wizards & Witches of the Rainy City, spotlighting such notables as Iambic Pentacular, whose watery double haunts the city; Antigone Graves, the VVitch of VVending Street; Hyperion the Hated; Oculam the Oracular; the Kandive, Agar Yaminnu; and the ever-changing and unchanging Sandestin.
   The Patrons of the Rainy City, powerful and notable people in the city who need something and need divers, adventurers, and renovator to get it for them
   The Gangs of the Rainy City, who prowl the flooded streets of the city carousing and causing trouble
And much more! 
Bonus Stretch Goal — Reached!!
The campaign also now includes a single stretch goal (the only one we will have). Upon reaching the $2000 funding level (which we did!), we will include for free a 11x17, quarter-folded poster of the Rainy City map for all backers at the Citizen reward tier! So not only will you get a map in the center of the zine, but if we reach this goal, we'll give you another one double the size to gaze at lovingly and plot out your Rainy City fun.
Map of the Rainy City - which will be the centerfold of the zine!
The finished zine will be a 56-page, 5 ½ x 8 ½, saddle-stitched booklet, printed w/ black ink. Interior pages will be on a beautiful ivory color (Cougar Natural), while the cover will be a heavyweight stock (in Haviland Blue). As writing and layout finishes up, the final page count could change. 
Haviland Blue Print Test - Not Final, but getting there
Cougar Natural Print Test - Not Final
Cougar Natural Print Test - Not Final
If you'd like to see a sample of the zine's content, we have posted sample previews on our website of Vagabond Bay and Tower Cliffs. Go check them out!
Physical copies will be mailed in a sufficiently-rigid cardboard mailer through the USPS for US residents only (shipping is free). Digital fulfillment will be through DriveThruRPG. If there is sufficient international interest, we can certainly explore print on demand through DriveThruRPG as well. 
Back Cover Mock Up - Not Final
Once we have successfully funded, we will push forward with completing the project on the following schedule:
 March/April: Finish Writing & Development, Final Art Pieces
   May/June: Finish Editing, Proofreading, and Layout
   July: Printing & Shipping
  The Writer
Rich Forest really likes roleplaying games. He likes other things, too (stouts and porters, whisky, grilling, trail running, very snowy winters, and very rainy days), but, come on, roleplaying games! He spent much of his twenties and early thirties living outside the US (Germany, Japan, Hong Kong, and England), but he’s settled in back home in mid-Michigan now with the love of his life and four children, a dog, and a rabbit. In his spare time, he’s an English professor at Central Michigan University, where he mostly teaches linguistics. This one time, he wrote a whole book just about nouns.
The Artist
Bill Spytma is an illustrator, writer, painter, sculpter, carver and crafter. He’s also an amateur folklorist chasing after Black Dogs and an armchair historian staying up late at night gazing into Odin’s one good eye. He enjoys roleplaying games, funny costumes, sword fighting, and cold, snowy weather.
The Mapmaker and Editor
Andrew Devenney’s first exposure to roleplaying games was the Moldvay Basic D&D set, which he used to make an elf named Luke (after Skywalker, of course) when he was the ripe old age of six years old. To say he was hooked after that is a bit of an understatement. Married with spawn that looks eerily just like him at their ages, he currently resides in scintillating Mount Pleasant, Michigan, where he occasionally teaches students about stuff at Central Michigan University. Because he doesn’t have enough to do, Andrew also co-writes and produces historical documentaries through his company, Stratigraphic Productions. He wears many hats. What’s one more?
The Company
We founded Superhero Necromancer Games so that we could produce the kinds of games and settings we enjoy playing. And A VISITOR'S GUIDE TO THE RAINY CITY is the first step in a whole slate of rpg books we'd love to make for you all. For updates on anything else we plan in the future, sign up for our mailing list. Or follow us on Twitter, Instagram, and Facebook.
campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
This is the first Kickstarter for us as a company (and the first for each of us individually as well), but we have researched RPG Kickstarters of varying sorts over the years, noting best practices and listening to advice from more experienced hands at crowdfunding campaigns.

We have also made a number of choices with this project that should help minimize any delays or difficulties with fulfillment:

1) All work for the VISITOR’S GUIDE is being done in house by us (that means, writing, editing, layout, and art), so there are no potential delays due to external collaborators;

2) Work on the zine is in progress right now, with several sections already written, edited, and in early layout, cartography finished, and many art assets completed;

3) We have kept the project simple, with no stretch goals (well, one stretch goal!) and only three basic reward tiers. The funding goal of the campaign is basically needed to cover the cost of printing a small print run of the zines and mailing out physical copies to backers; and

4) We are working with a local printer, so that any quality control or delivery issues can be quickly managed and costs kept as low as possible.

Life can come at you fast, but we feel that, with the limited scope of the project, the work already finished, and the steps we’ve taken not to bloat the project beyond our capabilities, we have done what we need to do to mitigate the effect of any unforeseen delays.
